key_insight: MemFlow introduces a flowing, adaptive memory that dynamically selects and propagates the most relevant historical cues for each upcoming video chunk, enabling consistent long-context video narratives with lower memory and computation overhead.
problem_solved: Maintains content consistency across long streaming/generated video by replacing fixed, one-size-fits-all memory compression strategies with a context-aware, adaptive memory mechanism.
method: Adaptive memory retrieval: for each new chunk, selectively fetches historical cues most relevant to the generation target instead of using uniformly compressed history.
Flowing memory update: continuously propagates and updates compact memory representations across time so past references remain aligned and consistent with future frames.
Efficiency-focused compression & retrieval: compresses only salient information and uses fast lookup/update to scale to long contexts with reduced compute/memory costs.
impact: Makes long-video generation more coherent and scalable—practitioners can generate longer, consistent narratives with lower resource consumption and improved temporal fidelity. Useful for streaming generation, video editing, and story-continuity applications.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: incoming chunk → adaptive memory retrieval → generation → memory update (flow arrows to show propagation)
Heatmap/timeline: which historical frames are selected per chunk (shows dynamic, changing attention to history)
Before/after comparison: two short video strips illustrating consistency problems with fixed memory vs. MemFlow
Bar chart: memory footprint and computation vs. baseline methods, showing improved efficiency and scalability
paper_title: MemFlow: Flowing Adaptive Memory for Consistent and Efficient Long Video Narratives
paper_authors: Sihui Ji, Xi Chen, Shuai Yang, Xin Tao, Pengfei Wan
